Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The effects of climate-driven phenological shifts on plant-pollinator interactions and reproductive success
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reproduction in most flowering plants, including one-third of crops, is aided through pollination by bees. The nearly 4000 species of bees native to the USA may become more important pollinators of crops as honey bee populations continue to decline. As climate-warming continues, there is concern that plant and bee species are shifting the timing of their activities unequally, causing a mismatch in the time of activity. If plants flower when bees are not active, reproduction could fail. This project will investigate how shifts in the timing of important activities will affect how plants and bees interact, and the consequences for plant reproduction. Results will help to understand how climate change will affect wild plant and crop reproduction, with implications for biodiversity and global food production. The scientific workforce will be strengthened through support for the education and training of a doctoral student and participation of an undergraduate from an underrepresented group.

Climate-warming has altered the amount of phenological overlap between coevolved plant and pollinator species. Using forb and solitary bee species native to Montana, forb-bee community composition will be manipulated within enclosed mesocosms. Bee emergence and plant blooming times will be controlled by strategic overwintering and greenhouse management. Blooming forbs and emerging bees will be assigned to mesh-sided mesocosms following a factorial design based on phenologies. The effects of altered phenological overlap on forb-bee interaction patterns and forb reproductive success will be assessed by conducting bee visitation observations at each mesocosm and determining the number and mass of seeds produced for each plant species. Empirical evidence generated by this study will help pinpoint plant and pollinator species most vulnerable to the negative effects of climate change, as well as inform conservation actions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactions between bees and flowers provide bees with food to survive and reproduce while providing flowers with the pollen that plants require to produce seeds. Such bee-plant interactions support successful reproduction in nearly 90% of the 300,000 species of flowering plants and nearly ¾ of crops worldwide. Without interactions between bees and flowers, the majority of life on earth, including human life, would cease to exist. In order for bees and plants to successfully interact, bees must be active when plants are in flower. Because both bees and flowers are seasonal – bees are only active and plants only flower for specific portions of time during the growing season – the timing of bee activity and flowering must be synchronized in order for bee-plant interactions to occur. Temperature plays an important role in maintaining synchronization between bee activity and flowering by providing a common cue that both bees and plants can use to guide the seasonal timing of their life cycles. As the climate warms due to human activities, the temperature cues that determine the seasonal timing of bee activity and flowering are changing. In some cases, bees and plants are not responding equally to changes in temperature cues, resulting in a disconnect between seasonal bee activity and the timing of flowering among some bee and plant species that have historically interacted. Such disconnects have generating concern among ecologists that climate-warming will disrupt bee-plant interactions that are so vital to the health of the environment and to human-wellbeing.

 The objective of this research project was to investigate the impact of climate-driven shifts in the timing of bee activity and flowering on patterns of bee-plant interactions, as well as bee and plant reproductive success. One possible outcome of changes in the seasonal timing among bee and plant species is that some bee species will no longer be active during periods of the season that allow them to interact with flowers that they had historically interacted with. Instead, some bee species may find themselves together with flowers that they have not seen or interacted with historically. In this case, will these bees interact with these novel flowers? If the answer is yes, will these interactions be as beneficial to both the bee and the flower as interactions between species that have historically interacted together? These are the questions we set out to answer.

 To investigate the answers to these questions, we devised an innovative experiment that allowed us to manipulate the identities of bee and plant species within a bee-plant community by enclosing bees and flowering plants inside mesh-sided cages called mesocosms. Inside each mesocosm, we enclosed specific bee and plant species representing both historically co-ocurring species and possible novel future bee-plant communities that may result from unequal changes in the timing of bee activity and flowering caused by climate-warming. Once enclosed inside each mesocosm, we were able to record which bees interacted with which flowers, how often they interacted, and for how long each interaction lasted. These measurements allowed us to assess how patterns of bee-plant interactions may change when bees and plants are faced with the decision to interact, or not, with novel partners compared with interaction patterns that occur between more familiar species. In addition, we collected the seeds produced by the plants inside each mesocosm, as well as the bee offspring produced in artificial nests contained in each mesocosm. Collecting the seeds and bee offspring allowed us to assess how successful the plants and bees were at reproducing when allowed to interact with historically familiar partners compared with when we only allowed interaction with novel partners.

We found that, in general, most bees and flowers are generalists, meaning they have the ability to, and indeed will, interact indiscriminately with whatever partners are available to them at the time. This result may indicate that bees and plants will be resilient to changes in interaction partners caused by shifts in the seasonal timing of their life cycle. In addition, plant reproductive success, or the number of seeds produced, was not affected by the identity of bee species that we allowed plants to interact with, suggesting that plant reproduction may also be resilient to changes in bee-plant interactions caused by climate-warming. We are still working on the analyses to understand how bee reproductive success may have responded in our study. It is important to note, however, that our study only evaluated one possible outcome of shifts in the timing of bee activity and flowering caused by climate-warming. Other scenarios, for example where changes in the timing of an organisms seasonal life cycle occur such that interacting partners are absent, or when shifts in timing dirupt interactions between more specialst species - species that can only interact with one or a few other species - may have more negative outcomes.
